metadata.title: Piper J-3 Cub
aws::graph::propositions: Piper J-3 Cub Military Variant L-4 in World War II
The L-4 was primarily employed in World War II for artillery spotting.
The L-4 was primarily employed in World War II for training liaison pilots.
Short-range reconnaissance missions were not uncommon for the L-4 in World War II.
Medical evacuation missions were not uncommon for the L-4 in World War II.
Courier missions were not uncommon for the L-4 in World War II.
Supply missions were not uncommon for the L-4 in World War II.
The L-4 had a slow cruising speed.
The L-4 had low-level maneuverability.
The L-4's slow cruising speed made it an ideal observation platform during the Allied invasion of France in June 1944.
The L-4's low-level maneuverability made it an ideal observation platform during the Allied invasion of France in June 1944.
L-4 aircraft were used for spotting hidden German guns in the hedgerow bocage country south of the invasion beaches.
L-4 aircraft were used for spotting hidden German armored vehicles waiting in ambush in the hedgerow bocage country south of the invasion beaches.
The L-4 pilot generally carried an observer during operations.
The L-4 pilot generally carried a 25-pound (11 kg) communications radio during operations.
The load of an observer and communications radio sometimes exceeded the L-4's specified gross weight.
After the Allied breakout in France, L-4s were occasionally equipped with improvised racks of infantry bazookas.
The improvised bazooka racks on L-4s were usually installed in pairs or quartets.
The bazooka-equipped L-4s were used for attacking enemy vehicles.
An L-4 named "Rosie the Rocketer" was the most famous of these ground attack planes.
"Rosie the Rocketer" was piloted by Major.

text: The L-4 was primarily employed in World War II for artillery spotting and training liaison pilots, but short-range reconnaissance, medical evacuation, and courier or supply missions were not uncommon. During the Allied invasion of France in June 1944, the L-4's slow cruising speed and low-level maneuverability made it an ideal observation platform for spotting hidden German guns and armored vehicles waiting in ambush in the hedgerow bocage country south of the invasion beaches. For these and other operations, the pilot generally carried both an observer and 25-pound (11 kg) communications radio, a load that sometimes exceeded the plane's specified gross weight. After the Allied breakout in France, L-4s were occasionally equipped with improvised racks (usually in pairs or quartets) of infantry bazookas for attacking enemy vehicles. The most famous of these unlikely ground attack planes was an L-4 named Rosie the Rocketer, piloted by Maj.
